biogHist.abstract: Withnell House was located in the Perth suburb of Mount Lawley. It was a hostel run by the Salvation Army from 1952 for boys who were Wards (migrant or Australian-born) who worked in the city. Withnell House ceased to be a hostel for boys in 1969. From that time, the building became known "Withnell House Girls' Home"; it accommodated residents and staff from transferred to Mount Lawley from the former Salvation Army Girls' Home, Cottesloe.
biogHist.p: Withnell House, Mt Lawley, was donated to the Salvation Army by Mrs Ellen Withnell in 1948. Some time after this, it was used by the Salvation Army Boys' Home, Nedlands, as an annexe. In September 1952, Withnell House became the Salvation Army's first Youth Hostel.

Withnell House closed in 1969. It is possible that any boys in residence at the hostel at time were transferred to the Hollywood Children's Village in Nedlands. In 1969, the building became a Salvation Army home for girls (residents and staff were transferred to Mount Lawley from the Salvation Army Girls' Home, Cottesloe). Because of this, the Mount Lawley home was sometimes called 'Cottesloe House'. Its official name was 'Withnell House Girls' Home'.

chronItem.event: Address - Withnell House was located at 68 Guildford Road, Mount Lawley

descriptiveNote.p: Withnell House took the name from the boys' home that had been located in the same building.

descriptiveNote.p: Some boys who had been resident at Withnell House may have moved to the Hollywood Children's Village, Salvation Army.
Withnell House Girls Home (1969 - 1972?) was located in the building formerly used to house the boys' hostel, Withnell House (1953? - 1969).

archref.repository: Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA, Withnell House child home closed file
archref.abstract: 'Withnell House History Book, cover' is a digital copy of an undated photcopy that is held in the Withnell House child home closed lever-arch file at the Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA. There is no personal information in the photocopy, but the item has a page of instructions that show what the History Book should record (p.3). It is possible that History Books were used in all Salvation Army institutions in Western Australia. The location of the original History Book is unknown.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: The Salvation Army Youth Hostel, Withnell House

archref.repository: Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA, Withnell House child home closed file
archref.unittitle: The Salvation Army Youth Hostel, Withnell House
archref.abstract: 'The Salvation Army Youth Hostel, Withnell House' is a digital copy of a photograph that is held in the Withnell House child home closed lever-arch file at the Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA. The photograph is undated, but the height of the palm near the sign suggests it may have been taken after the youth hostel opened in 1952 but before later pictures dated to the 1970s.
